Package me.zpath

Interface EvalContext

public interface EvalContext

An EvalContext represents the current state of the evaluation, but is primarily how the structure is navigated. A particular implementations for a data model will implement this interface.

  • Field Summary

    Fields
    Modifier and Type
    Field
    Description
    static final Object
    NULL
    The NULL object, which should be returned as a value when it's actually null (as opposed to just missing)
    static final Object
    WILDCARD
    This value will be passed in to get(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object) to represents the wildcard key

  • Field Details

    • WILDCARD

      static final Object WILDCARD
      This value will be passed in to get(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object) to represents the wildcard key

    • NULL

      static final Object NULL
      The NULL object, which should be returned as a value when it's actually null (as opposed to just missing)

  • Method Details

    • parent

      Object parent(Object o)
      If the node is not the root element of the structure, return its parent, otherwise return null
      Parameters:
      o - the node
      Returns:
      the parent node, or null if none exists

    • stringValue

      String stringValue(Object o)
      Return the value of the node when evaluated in an expression expecting a String. The exact meaning of this will depend on the Node language model, but in JSON it's expected that the native "string" type will return a value, and everything else will return null. In XML, Text or Attr nodes will return a value and Elements return null.
      Parameters:
      o - the node
      Returns:
      the value as a String, or null if this node does not evaluate to a String

    • numberValue

      Number numberValue(Object o)
      Return the value of the node when evaluated in an expression expecting a Number. The exact meaning of this will depend on the Node language model, but in JSON it's expected that the native "number" type will return a value, and everything else will return null. In XML there is no number type, so everything returns null.
      Parameters:
      o - the node
      Returns:
      the value as a double, or null if this node does not evaluate to a number

    • booleanValue

      Boolean booleanValue(Object o)
      Return the value of the node when evaluated in a boolean expression. The exact meaning of this will depend on the Node language model, but in JSON it's expected that everything other than false or null would return true. In XML, everything returns true.
      Parameters:
      o - the node
      Returns:
      the value as a boolean

    • get

      Iterable<? extends Object> get(Object o, Object key)
      Return the first child of this Node that is stored with the specified key, or an empty iterator if this Node has no matching child, or no concept of children stored against a key (i.e. it's not a map).
      Parameters:
      o - the node
      key - the key, which will never be null and may be WILDCARD, a String, and Integer, or (theoretically) some other type. If the model chooses to interpret a String value like "@*" as some sort of wildcard match that's OK.
      Returns:
      the set of nodes matching that value, or an empty collection

    • type

      String type(Object o)
      Return the type of this Node. The values depend on the source language but we suggest at least string, map, list, number, boolean or null are used as base types for JSON, and attr or tag are used when they apply. This value is only used by the type() function.
      Parameters:
      o - the node
      Returns:
      the type

    • key

      Object key(Object o)
      If this node can be retrieved by its parent element by a key passed to get(Object,Object), return the value of this key.
      Parameters:
      o - the node
      Returns:
      the key by which this node is retrieved from its parent, or null if it can't be determined

    • index

      int index(Object o)
      If this node can be retrieved from its parent via an integer index into get(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Object) and that integer really does represent an index rather than just a numeric map key, return the index, otherwise return -1
      Parameters:
      o - the node
      Returns:
      the index into this node's parent to retrieve this node, or -1

    • value

      Object value(Object o)
      Unwrap the specified object to a more primitive type. This is a called from the value() function and also Result.unwrap(). For example, this method would convert a DOM Text or Attr object to a String, and a JSON string, number, boolean or null to Java String, Number, Boolean or null
      Parameters:
      o - the object
      Returns:
      the unwrapped object, which may be "o" if its unchanged

    • isParent

      boolean isParent(Object o)
      Return true if the supplied object is a type of Node in this structure which could potentially have children; it's a list, map, DOM element etc.
      Parameters:
      o - the object
      Returns:
      true if the object is a potential parent, false if its a primitive object

    • getFunction

      Function getFunction(String name)
      Return the Function matching this name in this context, or null if there's no match
      Parameters:
      name - the function name
      Returns:
      the Function or null

    • getConfiguration

      Configuration getConfiguration()
      Return the Configuration that created this EvalContext
      Returns:
      the Configuration

    • getLogger

      Configuration.Logger getLogger()
      Return the Logger to use with this EvalContext, or null if not set
      Returns:
      the Logger

    • setContext

      void setContext(int index, List<Object> nodeset)
      Set the current "context" for this EvalContext
      Parameters:
      index - if nodeset is not null, the index of the current node into that nodeset
      nodeset - the current nodeset, which may be null

    • getContextIndex

      int getContextIndex()
      Return the index passed into setContext(int, java.util.List<java.lang.Object>)
      Returns:
      the index

    • getContext

      List<Object> getContext()
      Return the nodeset passed into setContext(int, java.util.List<java.lang.Object>)
      Returns:
      the nodeset
